baseline_groups.claim_summary: Working alongside friends increases worker productivity. The baseline tests whether having a friend present affects log productivity (logprod).
baseline_groups.notes: Baseline coefficient is -0.017 (p=0.84), statistically insignificant. The treatment variable has very limited within-worker variation (99.3% of obs have a friend present). The paper's actual main variable is proximity-based (working alongside friends), not just presence-based. Specs without worker FE show positive significant effects due to selection.

global_notes: Paper studies workplace friendships and productivity in a fruit-packing plant. The replication uses a simplified treatment (friend presence) rather than the paper's main treatment (friend proximity/position). 10 specs failed with collinearity errors. The null baseline result is robust across most within-worker specifications. Positive effects appear only in specs without worker FE (reflecting selection, not causation). Total valid specs: ~60 out of 79.
